Award.AwardTitle: Research Initiation: Exploring Enculturation of Engineering Students in the First-Year Engineering Program

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
The professional formation of engineers is a phenomenon of global interest. First-year engineering programs are being scrutinized and reevaluated for the purpose of attracting, retaining, and graduating an increased and diverse new generation of engineers. This research initiation project explores the enculturation of engineering students to the engineering profession during the first-year foundational engineering courses. Engineering enculturation is defined as the process by which a student learns the traditional content of an engineering culture and assimilates engineering practices and values. This work constitutes an analysis of a standard first-year engineering curriculum seen as an enculturation experience. The goal is to identify the extent to which the first-year engineering courses and interventions successfully welcome diverse students to the culture of the engineering profession. As it is the case for other professions with enculturation precedents (i.e. medicine and law), results will provide the foundation from which content, activities and programs can be more attuned to the engineering practice. The impacts of these results include the advancement in the knowledge of the professional formation of engineers through a cycle of theory of acculturation and improvements to the practice of the first-year engineering curriculum. Such impacts are transferable to all engineering years and specializations.

Taking advantage of the enculturation and acculturation advances of the social sciences, enculturation outcome factors have been identified (e.g. algorithmic thinking, problem solving, engineering design, etc.). This research seeks to advance the understanding of these enculturation outcome factors in engineering, approaching them from a diverse population perspective. The guiding research questions of this project are: (a) How do foundational engineering courses facilitate enculturation of first-year engineering students in terms of their performance in engineering enculturation outcome factors? (b) Among the engineering enculturation factors, which are perceived by students to be the easiest and/or the most challenging/difficult to achieve? (c) How do students' perceptions of enculturation to be an engineer change over time? The project takes into consideration subgroup differences in terms of gender, ethnicity, residency (domestic vs. international) and admission type (first time in college). A two year mixed-method research plan is proposed via students' performance scores and focus groups, and the associated results include an Engineering Enculturation Scale (EES) produced by exploratory and confirmatory factor analyses. The ultimate goal is to improve the professional formation of engineers through the lens of cultural acquisition.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the spirit of the research initiation program, the research team was mentored by a seasoned engineering education researcher and produced the following outcomes.

The major outcomes include six conference papers, one journal article and one subsequent NSF award. They also include the formation and training, in engineering education research, of six undergraduate students from diverse engineering majors.

The conference papers, entitled ?Exploring Enculturation in the First-year Engineering Program? (Year 3, 2, 1) were presented during the American Society for Engineering Education (ASEE) Conferences of 2019, 2018, and 2017 which provided a platform of discussion with other engineering educators. The papers progressively show results of the investigation. Major findings include the operationalization of enculturation factors affecting students during the first year in an engineering program (see figure 1). The other three papers, entitled ?Enculturation of diverse students to the engineering practices through first year engineering experiences,? ?First-year engineering students' perceptions of their abilities to succeed,? and ?Enculturation of diverse students to the engineering practices through first-year engineering college experiences? presented also during some of the mentioned ASEE conference include more granular analyses.

The NSF award that this research produced was on the side of computational thinking, one of the enculturation factors to engineering. Via the conference presentations, the PI recruited other two institutions creating a collaborative proposal that was awarded with Research Formation of Engineers funds in 2019. The subsequent enculturation study focuses on aspects of computational thinking that have not been investigated in the formation of engineers such as data analysis or impact of computing.

Six undergraduates have been supported and formed as engineering education researchers, one of them now in the multidisciplinary engineering master?s program. These students attended the ASEE 2019 conference and presented results. They have been involved at least two years in the activities of this grant.

At the time this report is being written, a final manuscript is being submitted to a high impact factor peer-reviewed journal. The manuscript encompasses the findings of this award focused on the factors of enculturation identified during the past three years.

Merit: The investigation awarded advanced knowledge in the area of the formation of engineers in their first year in the program. Engineering enculturation shed light to the process of assimilation to the knowledge, practices and values in the engineering profession and how engineers are shaped by the curricula.

Broader Impacts: Underrepresented groups in engineering have benefitted from this investigation. Aspects such as entry preparation level, reflecting privileged status, have been found relevant when enculturating engineers. Impact in other disciplines, and the cultures they assimilate their novices into, have also been investigated and compared to engineering, thus advancing their understanding.
